editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it was Acted, with great Applauſe, by their Majeſties Servants at the private Houſe in Drury Lane.
LONDON, Printed for Will: Sheares, at the Bible in S. Pauls Churchyard, neare the little North doore, 1654.

list.item: Valentia, Daughter to the Mantuan Duke.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: MAturity and age have now at length
Im poſed on me a carefull providence
Both for my Dukedoms ſafety, & the good
Of our moſt hopefull Son Prince Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You grow to ripeneſſe, and my thoughts are fix'd
To have you troth-plight to ſome noble wife,
That in my aged yeares I may have comfort
In your faire iſſue, I would have you marry.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Marry my Lord!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I, marry Proſpero.
I have labour'd with a neighbour Prince, poſſeſt
Of a faire Daughter, to confirme a match
'Twixt thee and her, and 'tis concluded firmly;
Her name Valentia, ſhe his only child,
By which a ſetled League grows 'twixt our Dukedomes,
And thou by this art the true hopefull Heire
Of both out rich and wealthy Provinces:
Your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I am free, my Lord, as th' uncurb'd aire,
That comes not within limit, as the light
That nothing can impriſon. Shall I truly
Speake my own thoughts, and not diſſemble with you?
I that am free 'mongſt men, and uncaptiv'd
To any, ſave the duty bound to you,
Am loath to make my ſelfe a womans ſlave,
Briefely, my Lord, I have no mind to marry.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not marry boy? Oh, knew'ſt thou what a ſweetneſſe
And harmonie's in loves bleſt fellowſhip
Thou wouldſt embrace it gladly; this bleſt union,
This true-loves knot the Gods themſelves do tye,
And none but death diſſolves. And what's Virginity?
A ſomething-nothing, ſingularity
Unſociable, ſo ſlightly reckon'd of
That either Sex, but to thy number grown,
Has a deſire to leave it; be perſwaded boy;
Thou haſt beheld the Picture, and it promiſes
A perfect Lady; hadſt thou ſeen the ſubſtance
Thou wouldſt condemne the workman for ſo ſcanting
Her rare compareleſſe beauty. Marriage,
Why 'tis an honour, Emperours, Kings, and Princes,
From the Pallace to the Cottage held it facred
And in a high religious reverence.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, I will be ſteer'd by you;
Even through the turbulent Ocean of this life,
Where many dreadfull tempeſts threaten us,
I ſhall be ſwai'd by you, and entertaine
This ſweet captivity,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Then art thou wiſe—the news. Flouriſh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Embaſſadours from Mantua crave admittance
Touching affaires of ſtate.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Admit 'em— Enter Embaſſadours.
Lords, your arrivall is in happy ſeaſon;
The marriage ſo long treated 'tween the Fathers
Shall by the Children be confirmed at length,
'Tis now on foot.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your grace miſtakes the tenour,
And the ſtrange purpoſe our Embaſie;
The Prince our Maſter lets know by us
That your alliance highly he diſdaines,
Contemnes your love and neere affinity,
And for juſt reaſons, to himſelfe beſt known,
Deſires your oppoſition; for the marriage
Treated between you, eſteemes his Daughter
Much undervalued, and not rated truly
To her beſt worth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pauſe Lord Embaſſadour,
So high hath thy words incer s'd our ſpleene,
And ſet ſo juſt an edge upon our wrath
That we want patience to beſtow an care
Unto thy harſh concluſion: Tell thy Lord,
We did not ſo much over-prize his love
As here his hate held in the baſeſt ſcorne;
Nor can he ſo much undervalue us
As we his Contracts and Confederacy;
And for thy ſelf-preſumptuous Mantuan Lord,
We favour thee to let thee undiſgrac'd
Depart our Court, be gone without reply,
Not Matuans, but Mantua we defie.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Let me conclude my Meſſage.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Convey him hence;
Diſdaine our fellowſhip! Mantua ſhall know
His ſtate ſhall leſſen whilſt our glories grow.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I, but, my Lord, I hope the match is not broke off
Betweene me and the faire Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh boy, didſt thou but know what marriage were,
How full of troubles and contentions,
Thou wouldſt forgo it gladly; who that's free
Would be confin'd to baſe Effeminacy?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But that which hath made in me the deepeſt impreſſion
Is the rare Picture of the Lady Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The Painter flattered her, in having her
Thou haſt a painted Miſtris, of her ſelfe
The Lady is miſhapen and deformed.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Nay, take me with you, my Lord,
I have beheld her Picture, and it promiſes
A perfect Lady; had I ſeen the ſubſtance
I ſhould condemne the workman for ſo ſcanting
Her rare compareleſſe beauty; theſe were your own words,
My Lord, or I much miſunderſtood them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: They were indeed, my Lord, I am witneſſe to them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well ſince your Grace has no purpoſe to have me marry,
Shall I have your beſt furtherance to travell?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, any thing to weare out the remembrance
Of Mantuas Daughter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Another boone, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's that Coz?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That I may be his Partner in his travell, his aſſociate
To beare him company, nothing elſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Have your deſires.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I embrace your fellowſhip,
Ile travell, but whither? to have a ſight of the faire Valentia,
There ſhall be the period of my Voyage;
What though her Father and mine be oppoſites, ſhe and I
May happily agree well enough when we meet together.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My Lord, what limit ſhall we have to play the wandring Knights in? Or how long ſhall it be ere we ſet forward on our Journey? We were beſt go well provided, for we muſt ſee Spaine, France, and England ere we returne.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Some ten daies hence you ſhall ſet forward,
Your ſtay hath a yeares limit.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Then come, faire Coz, we muſt provide our ſelves;
Her Picture's lovely, and it much contents,
And I muſt ſee the face that it preſents. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your youths cannot outſtrip my gravity,
I have you boyes, and aime at your intents;
This cunning ſuit for travell is a colour
To ſome cloſe practice to deceive my age,
But I ſhall wind them both, Coſmo.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The mannage of our State we leave to thee,
Whom we know wiſe and gravely provident;
Our purpoſe is to chaſe theſe travellers,
Whoſe voyage we miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: 'Tis dangerous
Unto your noble perſon, full of hazard
And doubtfull perill.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I am confident,
Diſſwade me not, for my intent is fixt;
In ſome ſuſpectleſſe ſhape Ile after them,
And ſound the inmoſt of their thoughts, yet paſſe unknown;
Coſmo regard your charge whilſt I provide. Flouriſh.
To find that craft they with ſuch cunning hide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You have breath'd defiance then.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And how did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: With ſuch ſcorne
And proud contempt, that with far greater ſpleene
He threatned us than we could menace him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No matter, this late difference pleaſeth us,
You have demean'd your ſelfe even to our wiſh,
Now leave us to our private meditations. Exeunt. Em.
Come hither Sirra, I repoſe in thee
Much truſt and much aſſured confidence,
I have brought thee up of a youth boy, I have.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You have if it ſhall pleaſe your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy Father was a good old ſervitour,
I lov'd him well, I did, indeed I did,
Beleeve it, for I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I beleeve your Lordſhip without ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou knowſt my Daughter ſhould have been affied
Unto Verona's Son Prince Proſpero,
I know thou knowſt it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I have had, if it pleaſe your Grace, ſuch an inckling,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But a difference ſince
Hath falne betwixt us, nay, in ſuch a manner
That by our Leagers we have threatned war,
And war is like to enſue to come to thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: If it ſhall pleaſe your honour, Ile ſave you that labour and come to you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Conceive me, I will come to that concerns thee,
Thou knowſt how deerly I affect my Daughter,
I, and how deerely I affect my Gold,
Speake, did I ever yet part with one peece
To guerdon thee, a ſigne I lov'd it well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No, never, if it ſhall pleaſe your honour, Ile do you right in that, you everlov'd me too well to give me any thing, I have ever heard you reported for as covetous and niggardly a noble Gentleman as ever bore ſway here, you are one of the moſt cloſſe-fifted Carpenters that ever bare rule in Mantua.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To keep my Daughter that ſhe marry not,
By which I like wiſe may reſerve her dower,
I have devis'd this oppoſition
'T weene Valentia and Prince Proſpero;
More Sutors are now reſident in Court,
But to prevent them Ile deviſe a Tower
In which to ſhut my Daughter ſo impregnable
And full of dores, of which Ile keep the keyes,
That ſhe in vaine ſhall ſtrive to iſſue out,
Or they to enter in; this ſtrong foundation
Is laid already, workmen are employ'd,
And all things promiſe proſperous ſucceſſe;
In this employment thou ſhalt have a charge,
An overſeers place, becauſe I know thee
Simple but ſure of faith: wee i truſt thy reach,
As far from craft as cunning, truly honeſt
Becauſe not over wiſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I muſt entreate your Lordſhip I may have a paire of Chopeens, or ſome high Cork'd ſhooes, or elſe I ſhall never
play the overſeer well; or if your Lordſhip will allow me but a Ladder, I warrant you I will overſee your workmen.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No more, there ſhall be order from our Treaſury
To furniſh this rich building—

div.stage: Enter Florence, Ferrara, Julio, Valentia, and Dutcheſſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Our welcome would ſhew better,
If we could heare it from the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: They come well that ſpeed well, if we could find our ſelves well ſped, then we ſhould not doubt to preſume we were well-come.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lord Julio, are the toyles prepar'd and ſet for our appointed game.?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They are my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then Princes we devote this day to paſtime
And chaſing of the Stag, theſe beauteous Ladies,
That muſt this day take leave of liberty,
Shall in our ſport aſſociate us; Valentia,
And you moſt beauteous, and my deareſt Love,
I here proteſt my ſelfe your Guardian,
Hoping to ſee you, ere two months expire,
The Mantuan Dutcheſſe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I hope no ſuch matter; but my Lord,
Am I your Deare, as you proclaime me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My deareſt Deare.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then being in the chaſe I ſhall feare in the hunting:
To come neare you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your reaſon Sweet.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Left being your Deare you ſhould ſtrike me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Still is this Lady croſſe to my deſignes,
But time may worke her; Daughter, mount your Steed,
And Lords to horſe▪ the morning grows upon us,
And ſteales towards midſt of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We but attend
Your Highneſſe company.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Lady, this day I will not ſtart from your ſide.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You'l be worſe to me than a ſtitch then.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor will I leave you Lady,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And yet you ſhall have free leave to leave me when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We trifle houres, found out your bugles ſh
And the thick aire with pleaſing ecchoes fill. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To ring thy knell, for this day thou art doom'd
To periſh by the hand of Iulio— Hornes.
The Mantuan Prince
Is now upon the Chace, I heare the cry,
But ere the ſtagg fall the proud Duke muſt dye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Harke what a ſhrill applauſe doth welcome us
Unto the Mantuan Confines.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It ſeemes the Duke or ſome of his traine
Are in the Forreſt chacing ſome game;
Nay, it muſt needs be ſo of neceſſity, they would not elſe make
This noyſe unleſſe they were all horne-mad.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: If I ſhould come a wooing, noble Coz,
I ſhould preſage the Muſick of theſe hornes
Might, to my future match, prove ominous;
But now let's mixe our ſelves amidſt the Traine,
And ſee what faire adventure may befall us.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sever our ſelves, it may be that ſweet face
Your Father prais'd may meet us in the Chace.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I like well this diviſion, come let's part,
And let's be henceforth ſtrangers, thus condition'd,
The firſt that can prefer himſelfe, or ſervice
Unto the Duke, or gaine his ſoveraigne grace
Shall for his friend provide ſome eminent place.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am pleas'd my Lord, then come let's mount away,
The morning's old, and we ſhall loſe much day. Exeunt. (Horns.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: With theſe Italian tricks villaines oft maske
Their grim bloud-thirſty fronts, and when they purpoſe
To act ſome horrid murder, if prevented,
Thus paſſe unknown, theſe bought I of a Jew,
A fellow that profeſſeth villaine;
Ile dog the Duke, whom if I can but ſingle,
Or light on from his Traine, but thus, 'tis done,
The Dukedome ſeiz'd, and faire Valentia wonne;
Auſpicious hell I thank: thee, thou art ſtill
True to black deeds, and friend to ſuch as kill—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My horſe hathfail'd me, and I forc'd on foot
To lag behind, my Traine have left me all,
Led by the muſick of ſo faire a Cry,

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: To find a place where thou maieſt fitly dye.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Who named death to me?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: One whoſe powerfull hand▪
Shall guide thy Dukedome, Daughter, and thy Land,
And at one blow gaine all—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And we ſo nigh,
The ſlave that threatned death himſelfe ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Prevented. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Courage, my Lord, the traiterous groome is fled,
And you ingirt with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Noble ſtranger,
The life thou haſt given me ſhall be ever thine,
And thanke the ſtars that brought thee to my reſcue,
They ow'd thee a great fortune, thou haſt ſav'd
The Mantuan Duke from death.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Are you my Lord,
The noble Mantuan Prince? what Traitours hand
Durſt threat your life?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know not, gentle ſir,
But for your ſelfe thus much preſume from me,
You ſhall be ever ours, to none more deare,
By whom I am freed from treaſon, death and feare.

div.stage: Enter Iulie, Florende, Ferrara, Valentia, Dutcheſſe, and Montecelſo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This way, my Lords, I ſaw the Duke in perills
An ugly ſlave, his face much Vizard-like.
Aſſail'd the Duke, and with his weapon drawn
Fled through the Foreſt, I purſu'd the Traitour
Whileſt I had breath, but fears and guilt of conſcience
Gave his ſpeed wings; but ſee my Lord's in ſafety,
Whoſe welfare I ſalute thus on my knee,
Glad in my ſoule that he from death is free.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Father threatned I bleſt be that faire hand
That wrought his ſafety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thanke this Gentleman,
This noble youth, 'tis he by whom I live,
Never ſo neare my death, never ſo neare it,
So mortall men are ſtill when leaſt they feare it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh do but tell me, thrice renowned ſir,
How I may ſhew me thankfull to your love,
Whoſe noble hand preſerv'd my fathers life.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam, your grace, your favour and good thoughts
Are gifts above my merit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Stranger, thou haft wonne the opinion and ſuffrage of the whole Court, and bound the Prince of Florence to be thy gratefull debtor.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We made haſt
To the Dukes reſcue, but it was thy fate
Our valours to prevent, we came too late.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yet did Lord Iulio, with what ſpeed he might, haſte us to this great danger.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: 'Twas my duty
And ſervice to my Lord, whom thus to ſee
Secur'd from death glads, almoſt frantiques me;
Legs for my life I thanke, and thou my braine
For making up this broken flaw againe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We thanke you Iulio, chiefely you faire ſtranger,
Whom for your ſervice we will raiſe in Court,
And breaſt next our moſt deare Valentia;
But ſhe is for the Tower bar'd with twelve doores,
And this the laſt day of her liberty,
That's our next buſineſſe; once more welcome ſir,
Attend on us to Court, our happy fate
Hath given me ſafety, and advanc'd thy ſtate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh faire Valentia!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My Lord, if you had been born leſſe than a Prince, yet you have wrought your ſelfe into grace.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here ſet a period to our travels, make a full point here.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And that, my Lord, is the full end of a ſentence; but ſhall we give over travell till we have ſeen ſomething worth ſeeing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Worth ſeeing ſai'ſt thou? what's Valentia?
Travell from Pole to Pole, ſtand at the Center
And progreſſe round about the ſpatious ſignes,
Or, were it poſſible, ſit with the Sun
In his high noon▪ tide glory, and from thence
Survey the Kingdomes of this lower world,
Thou canſt not find her match, Apollo's haire
Is dull to hers, her fingers, hand, eye, front.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Take me with you my Lord: This marvellous thing you call her beauty, is it ought but ordinary fleſh and bloud? Are thoſe gold wiry haires with which Apollo might go ſtring his Harpe, are they ought but the plaine haires of her head? Her Ivory palme, that doth in touching melt, embroidered with blew artires, is it ought but a Ladies hand and fingers? And this ſtrange thing, this wonder of the world, whoſe peere cannot be found betweene the Poles, are not all theſe nine wonders in one, ſhe that was here even now, the Dukes Daughter Valentia?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh my deare Montecelſo, this I know,
But ſuch an admiration hath ſurpriz'd
The freedome of my ſenſes, that it robs me
Of my true judgement.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be advis'd by me▪ you love this Lady, but ſo ſtrict is like to be her impriſonment, that you may as eaſily paſs by the gates that Cerberus keeps, as through the doores of this Caſtle; you are already in favour with the Duke, do but preferre me to be overſeer of the worke, if I do not▪ worke it ſo that I will bring you to overſee her, turne me out of my office as one not worthy the name of an Architecture.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
I ſhall commend thee for a man well skill'd a ſuch great ſtructures, it may be the Duke
May truſt me on my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And if I do not make him dote as much on you for your valour, as you make him enamour'd on me for my skill in building, may this Tower turne to the Tower of Babel, and make a ſecond confuſion betweene us, there remaines for you nothing but this, to winne the favour of the Lady; and for your acceſſe to her, if I do not teach you to counterfeit all the Dukes keyes, turne by all the wards of his locks & lay open all the Jurie of his twelve doores that he hath pannell'd againſt your entrance, report me to be no man of my trade▪ Away my Lord▪ leave this melancholly, walke by her window▪ and caſt ſheeps eyes that way towards her Chamber, let me alone to ſtand Centinell and watch if the Duke come▪ Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Clowne, a Smith, a Maſon▪ a Bricklayer, a Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Come on my maſters, the Duke has appointed me to be Overſeer of his workes, the building of this Tower is put to my indiſcretion; therefore come every one of you, and from me take your directions; what are you?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am a free Maſon, and expert in ſquaring ſtone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A good proper ſquare fellow, if your trade be in ſtone,
I make no queſtion but you will worke hard.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I warrant you ſir Ile do my endeavour; will you give us directions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Firſt you muſt make a faire large poſt at the entrie.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I warrant you Ile make a large porch that any Lady ſhall go in and out at pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: To ſee how you miſtake; you muſt make it that no body can go in and out at pleaſure but only my Ladie, it muſt be too wide for any that's leſſe than ſhee, and too ſtrait for any thats greater than ſhe, you conceive me.
sp.l: Oh ſir, 'tis not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Tell not me of poſſible, ſuch directions I had, and ſuch an one I muſt have made▪ Then muſt I have faire bay windows that muſt alwaies ſtand open and give no light, that they that ſtand without and looke in may ſee no body within, and ſhe that ſtands within and looks out may ſee no body without▪ the
reaſon is, my Lord meanes to keep his daughter in that Tower, where ſhe muſt neither ſee nor be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then none muſt offer to looke out from the inſide, nor in from the outſide, elſe 'tis not within the compaſſe of workmanſhip.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Tell not me of workmanſhip, ſuch windows I muſt have made: Now Carpenter for you, you muſt make the doores of that faſhion that women may go in but men may not, and they muſt be of ſuch wood as will not let a Lover come neare it, for my Lord will have no Lovers come neare his Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then you muſt have ſome body to keep them out; here are wiſe directions!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: For you goodman Padlock, you muſt hammer out your Locks and Keyes with ſuch Art, that if the Duke, or any from him, offer to open, the Key may turne at pleaſure, but if any Lover or ſuſpitious perſon come to enter, Nonſum, non poſſum, non Licet eſſe Domi.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay, they muſt have no entrance there.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Smith, you have hit the naile on the head; What's your place?

sp.speaker: Brick.
sp.p: I have the charge of the brick-worke, and muſt build the Chimnies if you would give me directions.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Marry will I ſir, you muſt have a ſpeciall regard in your Chimneys that they caſt heat, though there be no fire in them, and the Kitchin Chimney eſpecially muſt every meale yeeld roſt meat without ſending to market, and ſo to worke for a ſpurt, and after merrily to dinner.

sp.speaker: Omues.
sp.l: A good motion. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Iulio, and Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: HAve you given charge, Lord Iulio, that my Dutcheſs
Be nobly ſerv'd as her whom Mantua loves?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And that Valentia be inclos'd and ſhut
From all her ſutors eies.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I gave ſuch order.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Enough now my Lords.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You give us faire words; but keep us from the ſight of the faire Ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft and faire, ſoft and faire.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: We know they are both ſoft and faire, and that's the reaſon we deſire ſo much both to ſee and feele them.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would beneath the ground ſels of this Caſtle,
By Miners craft, were plac'd ſome ſtrong Petars,
To which I would give fire and blow this ſtructure
Up into aire that priſons thus my Love;
But Iulio peace, and ſome advantage wait
To ſhew to her thy love, to him thy hate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord, I can compare you to none ſo rightly as to the King Aerifius, that ſhut up his Daughter Danae in a brazen Tower, but you know the end of it, there was a Jupiter that with a golden pick-lock broke through thoſe brazen gates, and made the maid a mother. Now if
sp.l: I were to chooſe a godhead, of all the gods that are
Would I, for her ſake, wiſh to be a Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: For men to be made gods it were a wonder,
You Iove, and neither have his power nor thunder?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shall I baile her my Lord? Ile put you in good ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But not in better ſecurity than I have put her in already,
Yet better would do well; oh for a man
Skilfull in Architecture, and compoſing
Strong frames and formes of building.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Now's my queſtion;
My Lord, there is a ſtranger in your Court
Whoſe outſide though it promiſe not much Art,
Yet is he ſo ingenious, and ſo apt,
Of ſuch opinion and direction too,
That could you win him to be ſo imploy'd,
As we ſhall hardly, for men excellent
Are curious of their skill, you cannot find
A man to match his skill in Italy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou wert I ſee, faire Knight, mark'd in thy Cradle
To do me all good offices, bring that man
To my employment, I will guerdon him
With more than he can aske.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, but my Lord,
He is a man alwaies ſo abſolute,
And ſtands ſo much upon his excellence
In fine contriving and rare edifices
We ſhall have much adoe to win him to't— Ent. Mont.
Here comes the man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, your due praiſe hath, like a harbinger,
Gone all the way before you to provide you
A place in my regard, you are moſt welcome,
You have not ſeen my Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, I have perus'd it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What thinke you of the worke?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis pretty, pretty;
'Tis well for moderne builders, homebred workmen,
'Twill ſerve: Yet let me tell you, worthy Lord,
They never look'd on high Mauſelus Tombe,
Never beheld a Grecian Pyramis,
Rich Craſſus houſe at Rome, Diana's Temple
At Epheſus, nor the grand City Caire,
'Tis well for them that are no travellers;
Saw you me draw a forme, or a fine modell,
The Fabrick greatly would enamour you,
But yet 'tis well enough, pretty, not famous▪

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Shall I entreat you to direct my workmen,
And I will weigh your paines down with reward.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your Tower as 'tis, my Lord, will ſerve the turne,
Is finely ſeated, and to keepe your Daughter
Cloſe from the eyes of ſtrangers, well contriv'd,
Yet could I by a plot, but why ſhould I
Engage me in ſuch worke? 'tis well already,
Well, very well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You can contrive it better, noble ſtranger;
Make triall of my bounty, by mine honour
It ſhall not faile your hopes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Did not I tell you at the firſt, my Lord,
He would be wondrous dainty of his cunning?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So moſt men are in things they beſt excell;
Shall I prevaile faire ſir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well, I am wonne
To end that frame your workmen have begun;
I have perus'd the ſcituation,
Find it ſecure and full of able truſt,
Yet one defect I find: Could you pick out
Some noble Knight, whoſe valour did exceed,
To build for him a Lodging neare that Tower
Where faire Valentia is to live enclos'd,
He, as a Guardian, or a Centinell,
Might keep continuall watch, defend the paſſage,
And keepe the place ſtrong and impregnable?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where ſhould I find a man worthy that place,
Whoſe valour might ſupply this my employment?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let me engage my perſon to that buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Accept of me my Lord, Ile be her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let the Ferrara Marqueſs be employ'd
In this adventure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Liſt to me my Lord:
'Mongſt other queſts, once as I travell'd Greece,
There, at the ſack of a moſt famous towne,
I ſaw a Knight, now reſident in Court,
Do ſuch high deeds of Armes, that living Hector,
Had he ſurviv'd to ſee his Chivalry,
Would from the Worthies nine have rais'd his name,
To have eterniz'd him with golden fame.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In our Court reſident?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes, that ſtrange Knight,
What wonders have I ſeen him do in fight!
Would he attempt it, all the plot were ſure,
Your Selfe, your Daughter, and your Tower ſecure;
But you ſhall hardly win him to attempt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That he is valiant I muſt needs confeſſe
To my lives ſafeguard I have prov'd no leſſe;
Oh every way my friend; renowned Souldier,
Pardon me that I have not done you honours
Worthy your high deſerts.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Alas my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My cares are deafe unto excuſe, and ſhut
Gainſt all deniall.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am exceeding loath.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I ſhall deſerve it, noble Gentleman,
I muſt not be deni'd, this skilfull ſtranger
Shall cauſe my workmen build you a faire Lodging
Next to the Caſtle, and adjoyning cloſe
Unto my Daughters Chamber: this is all;
Can you deny me this?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Your former honours
Beſtow'd ſo largely on my meane deſerts
Have been with me prevailing Oratours
Upon your part, and I at length agree
This skilfull Artiſt ſhall diſpoſe of me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Againe prevented.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: On all ſides happy, fortunate, and bleſt,
Now my diſturb'd thoughts attaine true reſt,
Only one bar unto my beſt deſires
Is the intire affection and true zeale
I beare the beautious Dutcheſſe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh my Lord,
You have entertain'd the moſt affecting wooer
In Europe, or the world, therein he's better
Than in his Architecture, he's but young,
Yet Tully ne're had ſuch a fluent tongue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hem'd in with all felicities about,
Having theſe helps what need I now miſdoubt?
You ſhall ſir beare from me moſt kind commends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Who, I my Lord? Alas.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come ſir, you ſhall
Unto the beauteous Dutcheſſe whom I love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You do not know my weakneſſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are ſtrong
In your acute words, and prais'd for your ſweet tongue,
A token I will ſend by you, that give her,
And in your own ſweet words my love deliver.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If need's Ile do't my Lord: upon my life
The provident Duke has found me out a wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow us Lords, I am full of jocund mirth,
My feares are dead, my joyes receive new birth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now Prince, was not this wrought out of Adamant?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: But what's the marke that all the ſeverall arrows ſhoot at?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This is the marke▪ marke it, I am made chiefe overſeer of the worke, and your Lodging is directly againſt the Chamber of the Lady: Now will I appoint a private doore to be made through the wall, by and through which you may have acceſſe, ingreſſe and regreſſe at your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou haſt builded in my heart a Tower already
Of ſteady and firme hope.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Take my word I am excellent at Architecture.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: But touching thy employment with the Dutcheſſe,
Art thou ſo mad to wooe her for the Duke?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, I will ſet him out in his lively colours, deale you as ſoundly with the maid as I will worke with the widdow, and I doubt not but we ſhall both live to be in the beliefe there are no Cuekolds but Batchelours, our ſtay is ſuſpicious, be it your charge to hire—
sp.l: A workman to make the private dore through the wall,
And leave it to my wit to cover all.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That be my care▪
Thou wooeſt a widdow, but I court a maid,
The way thou tread'ſt is eaſie, broad, and free,
But mine is ſtrait, and danger uſhers me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No marvell though Jove often went diſguis'd,
And in his rurall habit trac'd the earth
To heare and ſee th' affaires of mortall men.
I being a Prince have in theſe lowly weeds
Seen more than being refident in Court;
But I am now in Mantua, and thus far
I have purſued my Son by common tract;
The Duke and I are dangerouſly oppos'd,
And therefore this diſguiſe muſt ſhelter me;
The Mantuan Court Ile now ſearch ere I go
For Montecelſo and my princely Son—

div.stage: Enter Clown with a rule and line.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Let me ſee, let me ſee, make a doore ſo broad, I, ſo broad, and thus wide; now unleſſe I had the Lady here to take meaſure of her 'tis impoſſible that ever I ſhould make the doore fit▪ if a man take a thing in hand, it is for his credit to do it workeman like; now if I ſhould make the doore too ſtreight to pinch her body, or too wide to ſit upon her like a ſack, what credit ſhould I have by my workmanſhip?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Heaven ſave you ſir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Et tu quoque my friend; let me ſee, let me ſee, now have I forgotten whether the doore muſt be made for her to come thus, with her armes broad waies, Pilcher-faſhion, and a kembo; or thus ſide-waies, like a ſhotten herring.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sir, without interruption to your buſineſſe, ſhall I entreat a few words with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Hold here, hold here a little, thus high, I, thus high, juſt thus high; but now my friend, if I ſhould make it juſt thus high according to my meaſure, and then the party being yet but young ſhould grow higher, there were all the labour caſt away▪ come, come, I muſt have a new meaſure.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir, what means this? I underſtand it not▪
Pray let me aske you but one queſtion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Hold againe, hold againe, ſay my friend I make it of this breadth according to my meaſure, juſt to a haire; very good my
friend, but now the party being yet but leane that it ſhould be made for, ſay the party hereafter grow fat, or as the Fox that when his belly was empty crept through a ſmall hole into a henrooſt, and there fill'd his belly ſo full, that when he ſhould come out againe, there was no roome; Colon was grown ſo great, and ſo poore Reynald was taken in the manner, no, my friend, this muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I pray ſir to what end take you this meaſure?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why, my friend, becauſe I would do nothing out of meaſure, I hope you have not plaid the old caves dropper.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No ſir, but if your chiefe affaires be ended,
Let me diſcourſe with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My friend, as you have lent a hand to my Line, ſo will I lend an care to your tale.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's the beſt news in Court?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troth ſir nothing but this, that the Prince is magnanimous, the Courtiers egregious, the Ladies beautious, the place conſpicuous, and the building in hand moſt ſumptuous.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What ſtrangers ſo journe there, what men of note?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troth ſir there are only two, one is moſt brave at models and buildings, and hath undertaken a moſt brave peece of worke.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That's not my Son, he never ſtudied that,
No, not his friend.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But there is another, the fineſt ſweet-fac'd Gentleman, that ſav'd the Dukes life in the Forreſt, if you know not that you know nothing, if you know not him you know no body.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A moſt dainty man, much of my ſize, he hath a moſt leering lip and tempting eye, there is only this difference between us, for you would take us to be brothers, but that he has more haire than I, and I more wit than he; Father, you are not worthy to be held a good Subject, if you love not him that had like to have kill'd him that would have kill'd the Duke, he hath ſet me about this peece of work here, let me ſee, this blockhead of mine will never bring it to any purpoſe—Ent. Proſp. Oh here comes the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He interpoſe himſelfe and ſave the Duke▪
That looke, that face, that geſture is my Sons.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh well incounter'd, tell me honeſt fellow,
Haſt thou diſpatch'd the cloſe and ſecret doore?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not yet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What doſt thou with that Line?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am ſtaying here, that if ſhe ſhould come down this way,
I may take meaſure of her to make the doore fit for her body.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Away you aſſe, thou wilt betray my purpoſe;
But ſirrah on your life uſe ſeereſie,
And with all ſpeed diſpatch it; but what's he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A Fellow that wonders ſo young a Gentleman as your ſelfe ſhould take the Dukes quarrell in hand, and ſave him from the ſword of a Traitour.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis Proſpero my Son, ſhape, gate, and voice,
To heare his valour prais'd how I rejoice,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: This fellow at a bluſh looks like my Father,
Such ſetled gravity lives in his eye;
Nor is there wanting ought ſave power and ſtate,
Attended with the royall name of Duke
To make him the ſame man; but I digreſſe;
Come to your private taske, ſirrah be ſecret,
Or thy life paies for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I warrant you ſir, I would be as loath to hazzard my neck as you the Dukes favour, his favour once loſt may be got again, but my neck once broke, Ile not truſt all the bone-ſetters in Mantua to have it new ſet; feare not me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: This aged man is ſtill toſt in my thoughts,
And ever as I caſt a look on him,
His face grows more familiar with my eye;
But to our taske in hand, why do we ſtay?
His cloath of ſtate cannot be turn'd to gray. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Is this your travell Son? Oh heaven to ſee
The follies and the vaine delights of youth,
How headſtrong, and how full of violence!
Why ſhould he take this way? why ſojourne here
Within my enemies Court? If to revenge
My Injuries, why did he reſcue him?
Oh mine own Boy!
I muſt commend thee yet that could'it win love
Even of thy enemies, and honour'd fame
'Mongſt thoſe, that if they knew thee, hate thy name;
Ile liſten further till ſome fate bewray
The full intent of his enforced ſtay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Daughter is ſecurely clos'd and ſhut
In my new Turret, and the noble Knight,
As her bold guardian, hath his place aſſign'd,
Thoſe feares have end; now to my ſute in hand,
The ſtranger whom ſo late I entertain'd
Is my ſollicitor, and is directed
To meet and court the Dutcheſſe in the garden,
Where from this place I may behold their geſtures,
The manner of his courtſhip and conceit:
How is my heart diſturb'd 'tween hope and feare—
Comfort cold ſpirit, they now methinks appeare.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The greateſt inſtance of my love is, that I have given into your hands my liberty and life; my name is Montecelſo, and that noble Gentleman that reſcued the Duke Prince Proſpero, Son to the Duke of Verona, it lies in you either to ſave me alone, or to deſtroy us both; give me no deniall, ſweet Lady, rather kill me than diſcloſe me to the Duke, ſo ſhall you leſſen the ſuppoſition of your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: In that you are a ſtranger, I can no leſſe in courteſie, nor more in modeſty than to ſay you are welcome, though I have been truſted by many, I never betrayed any; I could call you raſh to truſt ſo rich a Jewel as your life unto the breſt of a woman, but though you be ſo over-bold to preſume upon me, I will not prove ſo over cruell to tyrannize over you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She talk'd a great long tale, and loud ſhe ſpake,
sp.l: To her again, do not that anſwer take.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, by all the honours of a Gentleman, my love is as pure to you, and as free from blemiſh as is the element of fire, or the white robe of Innocence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it is, I know it is.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
All the comfort I can give you is this, the life you
have committed to me ſhall be kept for you, the love you have proffered to me I will ponder on, I will never marry till you are beſtow'd, nor ever aſſume the name of wife till you meet with a Lady to call you husband.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Give me your hand of that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: I may well truſt you with my hand that have truſted me with your heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A match I hope, for ſee, they now joine hands,
My heart for joy upon the tiptoe ſtands;
Follow it now, ſtrike whilſt the Iron's hot,
I ne're was pleas'd till now with a fine plot.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But you forget in all this to ſpeake for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis true, I did forget my ſelfe, I muſt entreat you to thinke of him, but I do not entreat you to thinke well of him, as ill as you can poſſible; I beſeech you love to be out of his ſight in any caſe, and to love him beſt when he is fartheſt off: I would have you in all humility to honour him, but I would not for a world have you to marry him; have I yet ſpoke for him ſufficiently?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Good, good, well ſpoken, and well acted too,
He is not halfe ſo good to plot as wooe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: My Lord, the love we now celebrate betwixt our ſelves ſhould once have been ſolemnized between our parents, before theſe odds grew between the two Dukes.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Though the Dukes be at odds, let us make even,
Contracts are made on earth, but ſeal'd in heaven;
Madam, let the Dukes love be the colour to our meeting: I muſt go tell him the manner, for with much longing he expects my returne.
Once more let theſe our hands our hearts make ſure,
So thrive I as my love is chaſte and pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Againe, againe, faire fortune be thy ſpeed,
Once more joine hands, and then 'tis done indeed;
I knew the good Knight would not chooſe a man
That ſhould not fit my purpoſe, heaven I pray.
His place may take effect the other way,
And his intents as proſperouſly proceed;
But I muſt hence to meet him with all ſpeed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You wrong mine honour, and I ſhall complaine,
I charge you get you back the way you came.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My deed, though it ſeeme raſh, yet is begot
In as pure birth as truth, and as upright
As is the ſcale of Juſtice; I am free
From all mis-thoughts, then do not baniſh me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What are you ſir? whence are you? what's your name?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am your friend, ſhould you deſire to know
What my name is, alas my name's your foe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Being my friend, and court me in this kind
You ſhould have come and left your name behind.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I ſhould indeed, my name is Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prince Proſpero, and the Duke Verona's Son, Our profeſt Foe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Give me ſome other name,
Call me your friend and I am not the ſame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y'are not the ſame, you are th' advent'rous Knight
That from the forreſt-treaſon ſav'd my Father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I was Prince Proſpero when I reſen'd him,
And ſo continued till I ſaw your face;
But as my heart within your eye was toſt,
At once my hatred and my name I loſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was a kind foes part to ſave a foe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That kind foes part perform'd Prince Proſpero

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Such a faire foe that no more hurt intends
I ſhould prefer before a many friends.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lady, we ſhould have been elpous'd together,
But that our Fathers differ'd in the Dower;
Shall Gold divorce them whom the ſoule of love
Links in an endleſſe knot? I for your love
Firſt hazarded my life to come diſguis'd
Only to view your face, next I contriv'd
This private paſſage, known to none but us;
If this deſerve no love, no friendlie grace,
Confine my life if baniſh me this place.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If nothing but the reſcue of my Father
Should plead in your behalfe; it deſerv'd favour;
But when your travell, and your ſervent love,
Attended with year feature and rare parts,
Your ſtudious meanes to compaſſe my conſent
And hazzard of your fortunes many waies,
When all theſe plead together forciblie
They draw me in a treble folded chaine
Your zealous love to pay with love againe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I left my name behind me at Verona,
And now no more Prince Proſpero but your Love;
Weare this for me, and uſe in theſe affaires
My art, feare not, I will deviſe a meanes
To win your Fathers grant unto this match.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So we, my Lord, ſhall doubly be made friends,
I take it as an earneſt of your love,
And hope of my releaſe from this ſtrict bondage;
Accept of me in interchange this Ring,
My Father gave it me, keep't from his eye,
Or he will end our loves by jealouſie—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As I have been, I will be firme and ſure,
Long may the date of our chaſte love endure—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I prethee, ſweet Marqueſſe, ſince my ſucceſſe is ſo bad with the Dutcheſſe let's walke by the Dukes new edifice, and ſee if we can take a view of the young incloſed Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Content my Lord, the Dukes ſtrictneſſe adds but ſpurs to my deſire; for commonly what we are moſt forbid that ſtill we moſt covet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then ſhould you with ſome engine raze theſe walls
That interdicts your paſſage to that Tower;
Had I ſuch power I ſhould enjoy ſuch thoughts,
But Iulio is a Subject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind of ſuch generous and noble thoughts, let's take a view of the Caſtle, and ſpy where it is weakeſt, that there, if hereafter we ſhould invade, we may give the beſt and ſafeſt aſſault.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Now you ſpeake like a politicks Lover, come lets take a view of the building: But ſee, ſee, do you know him that's
talking with the Princeſſe Valentia?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't poſſible, Ile in and tell the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, leave me not behind, Ile ſecond you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Intreth Lad art good at that? you are a notable raſcall, can you come to't
So cloſely? is this your courage my couragious Knight?
Ile ſee how Mantua applauda this fight. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are deſcry'd my Lord, then poſt away,
Get through the private doore.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare not ſweet Lady, Ile ſo blind their eyes,
That we will ſtill live free from their ſurpriſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ten thouſand times adien, I am full of feare;
Where love inhabits danger ſtill draws neare. Ex.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ALL is too good to be true, but tell me,
And anſwer every word upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then tell me, tell me,
Didſt thou with all thy beſt prevailing words,
With all thy art, with all thy eloquence
Urge her to love? ſpeake that upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I did entreat her love:
With all my art, with all my eloquence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And did ſhe grant thy ſute?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou honeſt man, thrice happy be the houte
That I firſt met thee; now upon thy life
Tell me how ſpeed'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well upon my life.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And will ſhe love?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou haſt her promiſe

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But haſt thou, as thou art a Gentleman

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman I have my Lord,
I ſhould be ſorry elſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Did thy word proſper, took thy ſute effect▪
Will ſhe be wonne to marry at thy motion?
And did ſhe give her hand unto the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My ſute and words were both effectuall,
She's wonne to marry, and I have her hand
As witneſſe to the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Friend, ſweare that.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my life, my Lord, it is moſt true.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I thanke my ſtars.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thanke my ſtars too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thanke thee too, but for thy induſtry
This thing had never chanc'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nay, that's moſt certaine,
Had I not took my time and ply'd it throughly,
I had never wonne her heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But thou haſt wonne it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I, I thanke heaven my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And I thanke heaven my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She hath paſt her word and her firme promiſe to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It glads me at the heart, the very heart.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nor have I reaſon to be ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Once more I thanke thee friend.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis not ſo much worth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That be my perill, Ile 'bide the venture.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You are like to do that howſoever.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's gold, gramerey friend, I am thy debter;
This is but th' earneſt of thoſe rich rewards
Thou ſhalt receive from me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thanke your grace,
And I proteſt I would not for a million
My labours had been fruitleſſe, truſt upon it,
The greateſt aime of all my ſute is wonne,
Her heart, her hand, her free conſent is wonne
To match with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thanke my fate 'tis ſo;
But now about my other buſineſſe friend,
To looke unto my works; bleſt be the houre
I met thee firſt, but all is in heavens power. Exit Mon.
An honeſt and a faithfull Gentleman
Upon my warrant, and I dare relie
Upon his truſt and certaine honeſty—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, you are wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Diſparag'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And diſgrac'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I bring thee news, thy Caſtle is ſurpriz'd,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy Fort is taken.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And your Daughter ſeiz'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How may that be Lords? 'tis not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I ſpeake no more, my Lord, than what I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What I beheld.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And what theſe eyes have ſeen.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That ſtranger Knight, in whom thom moſt aff •• ſt.
I ſaw in a bay window court thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Emrbace her in his armes, and elaſpe her waſte.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She darting ſmiles at him, and the other.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nor did they bluſh, change face, or ceaſe their Courtſhip, but ſtood as at the gaze.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Iulie, and Lords,
You make me ſmile; have you ſo late perus'd
The ſcituation, and obſerv'd the paſſages,
And can you judge wit or the art of man
Can force acceſſe there and not uſe my keys?
Tuſh, you deceive your ſelves— Enter Proſpero.
Ha ha, ha, come hither Knight and laugh with me
At their three follies, they would needs perſwade me
They ſaw thee court my Daughter in her Chamber,
Where thou didſt publikely diſcourſe thy fill,
And yet theſe keys here at my girdle ſtill.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: They did me the more wrong; I ſcale your Tower▪
It lies not in the reach of humane power.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it well, tuſh, while theſe 〈◊◊〉 here
Were ſhe faire Danae I not Jove would feare.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You Tower is ſtronger the Aerifius hold.
Beſides, I am not Jove to raine down gold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't poſſible my eyes ſhould deceive me!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sure 'twas he, or the devill in's likeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's in this ſome witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You might as well ſay that you ſee this hand
Reaching as high as unto yonder clouds.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I ſhould have ſeen that Ring upon that hand
Once in my Daughters Chamber; oh my heart
Why doſt thou make ſuch traffique with pale feare?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He hath ſpy'd the gift, and knows the Ring I weare.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The ſame, the ſame, I will in and ſee
The iſſue of my feares, twelve locks, twelve keyes,
And every doore too double-barr'd with Iron,
She in the inmoſt rome wall'd round about,
It cannot be, and yet the Ring I ſaw
Urgeth my feares, and forceth me withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I know your, 〈◊〉 and muſt your ſpeed prevent,
But I delay; 'tis high time I were gone,
Twelve dores the Duke muſt paſſe, and I but one. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall I not truſt my eyes?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Though mine ſhould faile me I would witneſſe yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It makes me paſt my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's ſome ſtrange jugling could we find it out;
In all his acts your ſtranger let us trace,
And if we can, worke him ſome deepe diſgrace. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What haſt thou done Valentia, given thy heart
Unto a ſtranger, and thy Fathers foe?
I wrong the Prince, who with a heart intire
Purſues my ſpouſall love with chaſte deſire;
This match ſucceſſefully begun may move
Our Fathers hard hearts to a League of love— Enter. Pro.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wonder not Madam at my ſerious haſte,
Your Father on my finger ſpy'd the Ring,
And knowing it, is gone by the known way,
Marke you may heare the doores.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh my ſweet friend,
Haſte through the hidden way, leave it to me
To excuſe it, and retort his jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Adieu ſweet Lady,
Harke, harke the laſt doore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Deceit hath eyes behind, ſeems blind before—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What ſo ſad Daughter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not ſad but ſolitary.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I ſee no private paſſage, and my dores
Ranke in their wonted order; prethee Daughter
Shew me the Diamond I gave thee laſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Ring my Lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I the Ring.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, would your highneſſe uſe it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She moves a doubt,
I feare there's guile, and I muſt find it out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the Ring you meane:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I, 'tis the ſame;
Oh my own Girle, ſie my ſuſpitious thoughts
That you ſhould lead me to theſe jealous feares,
But Rings may be alike; my Deare, farewell,
Thou ſhalt not long in this cloſe priſon d well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So Proſpero hath promis'd, and Ile rather
Truſt him than you, although you be my Father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have obſerv'd ſir in your troubled looks
Much diſcontentment, you ſeeme in your appearance
To be ſome man of high and eminent place
With the great Mantuan Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not much ſir, yet out of a genetous ſpirit
In Pilgrims bred, ſuch as I am profeſt,
I would ſome cordiall counſels willingly
Beſtow upon you, did I know your griefes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have in me a naturall melancholly;
I have long aim'd at greatneſs, but betweene me
And that high point two ſtrangers ſtand oppos'd;
Canſt play the skilfull Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir I can.
Travell hath taught me much, and though now poore,
Yet in my better daies I have convers'd
In Courts of Princes; would you grace me then
But to prefer my ſervice to the Duke,
I would not doubt but to remove thoſe objects
That ſo offend your eyes; what are thoſe ſtrangers?

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: The one a young Knight that profeſſeth Armes:
The other Architecture, both are frequent
In the Dukes eare, and I, that in times paſt
Had all his boſome and his private thoughts,
Scarce now remember how his Chambers hang,
So ſeldome's my admittance.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Had you ſo much intereſt
In his paſt favours as to make my tongue
Free to his eare I would remove thoſe flatterers,
And plant you in your firſt deſerved grace;
But might I ſee theſe Gallants—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here they come;
The one I take to be a Conjurer,
The other his Familiar that he works with,
Ile ſhew thee reaſons for't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Obſerve them ſir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis true my Lord, this night the Dutcheſs lies in the Caſtle with the Lady Valentia, 'tis by the Dukes appointment, becauſe ſhe may be a comfortable kind Companion to his Daughter; now this night I have caſt it ſo, that we will be merry with them till paſt midnight.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But are the Ladies pleas'd it ſhall be ſo?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The bargain's made and ſeal'd firme with a kiſſe,
I ſet it faſt upon the Dutcheſs lips;
But come let's part till the appointed houre,
We muſt not be ſeen too familiar together.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou art my better Genius, I agree:
I have no good but what I reape from thee.
Mo. Farewel my Lord, only take heed of eare-droppers. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Did you heare that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, and it ſtrikes cold unto my heart;
Muſt they this night meet in Valentia's Tower)
The Devill hath made them picklocks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Patience ſir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Bid me be frantique, rather raile and curſe; at midnight muſt they meet?
Enough, at that fixt houre Ile rouze the Duke,
And put the Court in uproare, with his Guard
'Siege round the Tower, and take theſe Incubus
'Midſt their laſcivious paſtimes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Heare me ſir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am deafe to counſell, patience, grace and all,
Till in their midnight rapes theſe ſtrangers fall.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh were I now girt with a potent hoſte
Of mine owne people, and my ſelfe in Armes
Engag'd unto his reſcue, I could then
Aſsure me of my noble Son againe;
But I now feare his fall and ominous end,
Whoſe help bove men to heaven I muſt commend;
Yet Ile not hence, but note what ſhall enſue,
Heaven heare my prayers, thou art to juſt men true.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Madam, this night devote your ſelfe to mirth, whilſt your Father ſleeps ſecure in his Palace, Montecelſo hath promis'd to keepe his widdow waking; I aſsure you Prince Proſpero will be here too inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He cannot come unlook'd for, nor unwiſh'd,
So long as their intents are honourable,
So long their welcome is unqueſtionable.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Troth Madam we have exceedingly forgot our ſelves, we ſhould have had a banquet to have entertained them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Methinkes 'tis better as 'tis without, for the time, that ſhould have been ſpent in ſweet-meats to taſte the Pallat, ſhall be now ſpent in ſweet diſcourſe to relliſh the care.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
Fie, how long they ſtay, this houre is as long as three houres: I have obſerv'd one thing in Lovers houres, the time of
their abſence ſeemes hugely too long, and the time when they are preſent is three to one too ſhort.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And three to one is ods, but you are an old woman.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: That makes me long ſo much for a husband to make me even; what not yet come, nor yet? if they ſtay a little longer, I ſhall go neare to ſwoon thrice before they be ready to enter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No entrance if you love me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes at the private doore—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Imagine this night to be Saint Valentines day, when every bird chooſeth her mate, for that is the ſeaſon when they couple; I am here.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And I here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I am glad, my Lord, that you are here; yet I would be loath, my Lord, have my Father know that you are ſo.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That I am ſo ſeated, and you upon my knee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon my knees I beg that it may never come to his care.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, what ſhall's do?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Say what you will my Lord, but do nothing I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: If we ſhould do nothing, of that muſt neceſſary come ill, Ile prove it too; of doing nothing comes Idleneſſe, of idleneſſe comes no goodneſſe, of no goodneſſe neceſſary comes ill: therefore if we do nothing, of neceſſity we muſt do ill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: How well, my Lord, you can infer ill; but, my Lord, if you ſhould inſiſt much in this argument, it were more to expreſſe your oratory than honeſty; but my Lord, I know your vertues, and the opinion of them hath prepar'd you a moſt kind and loving welcome; we have nothing to entertaine you but words, and we can feaſt you with nothing but kiſſes; now you ſee your fare, fall to and welcome.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, I could everlaſtingly feed here, and yet preſume never to ſurfeit, I can but thanke you, and now I have given thankes, Ile even make bold to fall to.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You ſay you could find in your heart to offend my father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I madam, ſo for my offence he would everlaſtingly confine me to this priſon; why ſmile you Lady?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To thinke if my father ſhould ſteale upon you, and find you here, what a cunning picklock he would take you for, he would queſtionleſſe thinke you carried a falſe key about you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Tuſh, he hath made a Jury of twelve doores already to paſs upon my cauſe, and they have all given my caſe up not guilty—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Where's the Dukes Guard?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Begirt the Caſtle round.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Her windows ſhine with lights like blazing ſtars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Th'are in her Chamber ſure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Heard you that Madam?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The Caſtle round beſet.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And harke, above I heare the Dukes keys, down the private way, and leave the excuſe to us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, when my Lords?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This way my Lord, good night.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nay, ſtand not now on triviall Complements,
The Duke's at hand.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Farewell, Ladies adieu.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, if you love us leave us; Madam, how ſhall we anſwer this to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now my apron ſtrings if I had one on, Madam take your Chaire and counterfeit your ſelfe faſt aſleep, ſo will I, not a word now if you love me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thy very words are better to me than a Phyſicall potion, for they have caſt me into a ſound ſleep already; ſee I am faſt—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft, make no noiſe, the Chamber's whiſt and ſtill,
There's not ſo much aire ſtirring as would make
The trembling Aſpen ſhake; ha, faſt aſleep?
Search round the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I find no man here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here's naught but walls and Arras, and two Ladies
In depth of ſleep.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let's wake them my Lord and queſtion them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not for thy head that haſt deluded us,
And to this ſhame and mockery rais'd the Court,
Would I diſturbe them of a minutes reſt;
Thy envy unto ſuch as we have rais'd
For their deſert in Court hath ſtretch'd it ſelfe
Even to our high diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hell and the furies,
Am I againe deluded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fie Lord Iulio,
To call us in a mockery from our beds!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here to hunt ſhadows, ſure the fellow dreamt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray my Lord wake them, and reſolve them how Lord Iulio hath poſſeſt you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Pardon me,
They both are charm'd in ſilence, and their ſenſes
Confus'd in innocent dreames; I oft have heard
That what a man or woman waking thinks,
If they be queſtion'd in their depth of reſt
Their Genius or their ſoule will anſwer for them,
As their affections or their hearts inclin'd;
Of this Ile make a true and proſperous uſe,
And ſound them how their humours are diſpos'd,
And to my Daughter firſt, Lords ſtand apart,
How ſweetly doth my Girle become her reſt!
How ſound are her ſuſpites! Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She anſwers me, now art thou happy Mantua,
For thou ſhalt ſound the utmoſt of her thoughts;
Whom doth my Daughter moſt affect on earth?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I love none but my Father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh mine own girle, and wouldſt thou not have a husband?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile live and dye a maid.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's no deceit in this, there's no diſſembling,
Shee cannot ſtudy for evaſive ſhifts,
I thanke heaven I am reſolv'd: now Dutcheſs
Your turne is next, Ile try how ſhe likes me,
What thinks the Dutcheſs of the Mantuan Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: As of a fine grave noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Now ſhe ſpeakes her heart, this is plaine dealing;
And couldſt thou be content to marry him?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's my deſire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And live his noble Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I wiſh no better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mine own;
Moſt ſweetly may you ſleep, and nightly dreame
Of theſe poſitions, not for halfe my Dukedome
Would I diſturbe their quiet; come let's leave them,
Nay pardon me, Ile ſee the Chamber cleer'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Could I be poſſibly thus mock'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen,
Ile be the Porter, ſee I keep the keyes
Of theſe two Jewels that I moſt eſteeme;
Iulio, beware hereafter you incur not
Our wrath by theſe ſuggeſtions of untruths;
Come Lords to bed, I counſell you the beſt,
Goodnight my girles, and ſweetly may you reſt.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Are they gone wench?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I, and ſo gone that till they have ſlept ſoundly, 'tis not poſſible to fetch them againe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now Endymions fortune upon them, that being once aſleep they may not wake againe this forty yeares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Was it not well apprehended of me to ſay I lov'd none but my Father?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And was it not as well ſeconded of me to ſay in my ſleep I lov'd none but the Duke? Sure it muſt be in my ſleep if ever I lov'd him, for yet I could never endure him waking; but what ſhall's do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By my counſell let us even go to bed like loving bedfellows, and ſee if we can dreame of them that in time may become our loving bedfellows.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
With all my heart, now the Duke is confident of our affections, we may be the freer in the entertaining of thoſe whom we beſt affect; come, come, let's leave talking of this
counterfeit ſleep, and ſee if we can take a nap in ſadneſſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: content, and let all men learne thus much from us, that ſleeping or waking 'tis hard to o're-reach a woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yet all things go currant; if the Ladies were as nimble in their excuſe as we were quick in our paſſage through the private doore, I hope neither the Duke nor any of his Court can any way trace us in our proceedings; ſome Lovers would think me a moſt happy creature to enjoy the love of ſo beautiful a Lady, and for ought I know I may be ſo; but I have made a Vow never to marry a wife, but firſt to make ſome perfect and ſound triall of her affection towards me; but becauſe there is no woman that loves a man living, but ſhe will infinitely lament him dead, it ſhall be thought that I have drown'd my ſelfe, of which I will give the Court ſome aſſured inſtance, and afterwards living hereabouts in ſome odd diſguiſe, I ſhall truly underſtand how ſhe takes my death; if in any extremity of griefe, I will revive her with as great a ſurpluſage of joy; but if ſhe take it coldly, as a buſineſs that little concernes her, Ile leave her to the mercy of him that bids faireſt for her; and to my plot, I ſtay but for ſome company that may ſee me throw my ſelfe deſperately into the River, heare my paſſion and report it—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My worke and every thing belonging to the Dukes building being brought to ſome good paſs, I will ſtudy how to paſs the time, and for the better recreation of my duller ſpirits take a turne or two here by the Rivers ſide to contemplate of the beauty of my Miſtris; for indeed I am lately falne in love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No fitter man in the world to be the reporter of my death than this Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Upon a morning when I roſe to breakfaſt like a glutton,
I don'd my doublet and my hoſe, and eate two legs of Mutton;
Her bonny looks forget I not, nor teeth as white as amber,
Her face did ſhine like pewter-pot belonging to the Chamber;
My lovely Miſtris I eſpi'd as ſhe a milking went a,
But oh me thought at every ſtride her ſmock that ſhe had rent a;
Full pale ſhe look'd, for on her head a milk-paile was well placed,
Her lips were white, her brows were red, her body was ſtraitelaced;
But ſhall I now deſcribe her legs, for I durſt look no higher,
She went as if ſhe trod on eggs moſt ſoftly through the mire.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now to my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But oh a place beſides all theſe above both knees and thighs a,
Which ſpring, as ſhe look'd for fleas, did make my ſtomack riſe a.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Let Jove threat thunder, or bright Juno ſcold,
Mars threaten Armes, arm'd in Cyclopian ſteele,
He to my heels clap Boreas brazen wings,
Or mounted on the back of Mercury
With greater terrour ſcale the Olimpick heaven,
Then when the Giants muſter'd here on earth,
And darted mountaine tops at Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What mad fellow's this? he hath driven me quite out of my meditations, pray heaven I fall not into his fegaries.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But oh my beautious Dutcheſs, cauſe of this
My frenzy, lunacy, rage, and deſpaire,
I love thee dearely; yet becauſe my fervor
Shall no way croſs the noble Mantuan Duke,
I am reſolv'd to dye.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Of all the trades that are I love not this dying, poore Gentleman, would the Duke knew as much; but if love put a man into theſe perplexities, Ile take heed how I meddle with it, Ile e'ne ſhake hands with it, and part with it as it came.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Whom do I ſee, the Duke of Mantua's Joy,
She whoſe bright beauty enamours Jove himſelfe,
And makes him from his chryſtall throne deſcend
To 'bide with this faire mortal, thou art ſhe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not I I aſſure you, I am a man and no woman, if you will not beleeve me, I have a warrant about me to ſhew.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, thou art ſhe, wilt thou diſſemble love?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am not ſhe, looke here I have a beard.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis but the perriwig falne from thy temples,
And ſtaies upon thy Chin, thou art my Dutcheſs;
But ſtay, Ile place this border right againe,
And ſet it on thy front where it ſhould ſtand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Oh ſir, Ile bring the Dukes own barber that ſhall take
his oath upon a corporall book, that this is a beard and no perriwig; I am he that was overſeer of the Dukes worke, and not the faire Dutcheſs that you take me for, put on your ſpectacles, and you will ſee I am nothing like her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Then ſhe is loſt, and I undone withall,
Therefore Ile ſtrip me to the Ivory skin,
And as Leander did lively leape in,
My head beneath yon River I will run,
Neptune ſpread wide thy armes, for now I come. Exit running.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh ſave the man, ſave the man, now he flounces, now he flounders, yet he ſwims above water like a walnut ſhell, yet he ſprawles like a naked frog, yet he ſtrives for life, oh ſave the man, ſave the man; but now, now, now he ſinkes by degrees, now he is ſwallow'd, now he is choak'd, this is my comfort, he cannot chooſe but go with a cleane ſoule to heaven, it will be ſo waſh'd in the water before he come thither. Againe, againe, againe; now he lies ſtill upon his back and floates along with the tide, and now his ſoule is in the skies, he doth not offer ſo much as to ſtrive againſt the ſtreame, but ſwims as gently down with the tide as may be; but what a foole was he, that knowing he ſhould go ſo long a journey by water, and the weather ſo could too, would leave his cloaths behind him? Well, Ile e'ne take up his ſcatter'd Apparell, carry them to the Court, and there report what I have heard and ſeen, the poore Gentleman is well onward of his journey by this time, they had need provide him good ſtore of faggots, for hee'l be monſtrouſly wet when he comes to his Inne.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Iulio, Proſpero, and Dutcheſſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: LAdy, I underſtand and good tidings from you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: From me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis all one Madam, you at length are wonne
Unto a ſecond marriage.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Hath Montecelſo then told to the Duke
Of my free grant and yeelding to his love?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, I muſt have you freely reconcil'd
To the Lord Iulio that hath put upon you
Such ſlanderous imputations.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You my Lord
Can much with me, but were't for the reverence
I owe your Grace my ſword had character'd
My wrong upon his body.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, all friends.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My Lord, I yeeld my ſelfe, and here confeſs
In what high meaſure I have injur'd you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's too much to receive injury and make ſatisfaction too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He ſlandered you moſt vilely.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Told the Duke
You were ſafe lodg'd within Valentia's Tower.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Made us to girt the place with the Dukes Guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And at the high'ſt of night ſearch all her Lodgings
For you and th' Architector.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But who found you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None but two ſleeping Ladies▪ and they faſt
Surpriz'd in innocent dreames.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Was this wrong
To be endur'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where the guilt's confeſt
There pardon is ſoone purchaſt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile not beleeve
But there's in this ſome jugling, ſome ſtrange feat—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Roome for a bringer of ill news, for one that brings a tale will offend all your noſes, and a diſcourſe that will diſtaſte all your eares; who knows this Hat? who knows this Doublet? who knows this Cloake?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Theſe were Lord Montecelſo's; why my heart Art thou ſtruck cold with feare?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Theſe were my friends.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If I miſtake not theſe belong'd to him
Whom I prefert'd to over-ſee my works,
What news of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You that lov'd him, out with your eyes, and wipe your handkerchers, and as you look upon this Cloake provide for a ſhower of raine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Speake, what of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He is dead, he is fled, he is not wounded, but he is drowned, he is gone for ever, for he is leapt into the River.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Drown'd!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How came he drown'd? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Marry with water, belike it got into his mouth and choak'd him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's one gone yet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I meane diſcourſe the cauſe that urg'd him to't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
As I was walking by the Rivers ſide, muſing and meditating on ſome paſſions incident to men of my complexion, I ſpi'd this Gentleman ſtarke ſtaring mad, exclaiming on the beauty of this faire Dutcheſs, ſaying, that he run mad for her love; but becauſe he would not be falſe to the Duke his Maſter, that put him in truſt, he would rather ſhew himſelfe to be no better than a drown'd Rat than deceive him, and ſo very courteouſly
caſts away his Hat, very dolefully laies by his Cloake, very diſſolutely hurles off his Doublet, very deſperately leaps into the River, and very dangerouſly gives up the Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It drives me to amazement,
And I am wrapt in wonder.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh my Fate!
I am of all the moſt unfortunate;
Ile not out-live him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wherefore doth my Dutcheſſe
Shew in her looks ſuch ſad diſtemperature?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am loſt, there ſteales a coldneſſe through my bloud,
The Icy hand of death plaies on my breaſts,
And where it toucheth turneth all to earth,
And I am doom'd—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Look to the Lady, ſee ſhe faints.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How cheare you Lady?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ha, am I call'd againe?
Then like a ſoule diſturb'd in her departure,
And kept from reſt and downie quietneſſe,
Let me proclaime my anguiſh.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Patience Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ile not be patient, give me leave to drowne
My ſoule in brine, and in a floud of teares
Swim to my Love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The Dutcheſs is diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am ſo, I am deſperate, frantick, mad,
Go call yon Architector from the deeps,
And he ſhall build a Caſtle in the aire,
Where we will live together 'midſt the Clouds
And laugh at theſe poore mortals here on earth.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The Ladie's mad.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd, not I;
Cannot a Lady weepe, mourne, or lament,
Or ſpend a few teares o're a funerall hearſe
But you will judge her frantique, pray give leave,
Which of you here can hinder me to weep?
I am a woman

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am a man.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Women command teares,
Then pray let me beſtow ſome on a friend;
If you will dye go hang or drowne your ſelves,
Ile do the like for you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, not for me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Why ſhould I weepe for thee if thou didſt ſo,
Or thee, or thee, or any dotard here,
Yet if you pleaſe you may go try for me,
He clap at that well-acted Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh ſave the woman, ſave the woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow her Iulio, ſee her well attended;
Sure ſhe is Planet-ſtruck, or ſome ill ſtar
Hath in her boſome wrought this mutinous war,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile ſee well to her ſafety.

sp.speaker: Man.
