sp.l: Oh my Dutcheſſe!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Theſe are but womens paſſions,
And like a tempeſt, the more violent 'tis
'Twill be the ſooner blown o'r.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So I hope.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, perhaps ſhe counterfeits
To know how you affect her, if in this
You will compaſſionate with her, and partake
In this ſuppoſed frenzie.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis like ſo,
For if a man may truſt a ſleeping woman,
She loves me 'bove the world.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My Lord I know it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, I know it too, Ile never elſe truſt dreames.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But leaving this, I have a ſute unto your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speake and prevaile deare friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is a Spaniſh Lady my firſt Love,
Who heating of my reſidence with you,
Is travell'd thence to meet me in your Court,
I have notice that ſhe ſhortly will arive;
My purpoſe is to feaſt her in my Lodging
So lately built, next to your Daughters Tower,
Where if it pleaſe you with theſe Lords to grace 〈◊〉 ,
And taſte a homely banquet, I ſhall ſay
To you I am engaged every way.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will not faile thee, nor ſhall theſe our friends,
Wee'l grace the Spaniſh Lady with our preſence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have a ſute to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy buſineſs Groome?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: That for the good news I have brought you I may have ſome guerdon, ſome remuneration, as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This thy reward be, ſince by thy occaſion
My Dutcheſs of her beſt wits is depriv'd,
Wander for ever like a baniſh'd Caine,
Till of her ſence ſhe be poſſeſt againe
Dare not ſo neare our Court. Come Lords, let's in
To cheere her ſorrows, and her fate lament,
But to the man that can her fren • ie cure
We here proclaime what e're he can demand▪
If in the compaſſe of our populous Land.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Baniſh, what's that? can any man tell me what it means? let me ſee; Baniſh'd ſure is ſome ſtrange language, and for any thing I know the meaning of it may be, give him a hundred Crowns, or give him two hundred Crowns; and baniſh'd the Court may be come to the Court and there you ſhall receive them; the Duke was not wont to give me ſuch hard words; if he had call'd me Rogue or Raſcall, I had underſtood him, I had had him to a haire, but the word baniſh'd doth a little ſtick in my ſtomack; Baniſh'd! I will go feek out ſome wiſe man or other to tell me what the the word meanes, and what ſum of money, I may demand of the Dukes Treaſurer; Baniſh'd—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Save you ſir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And you my friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sir I profeſſe my ſelfe to be a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then you are the man that I deſire to meet, for I was ſeeking a wiſe man to tell me the meaning of a ſtrange word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Unfold thy mind; I ſhall reſolve thee truly▪
Lye it within the power of humane skill.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Thus Stands the caſe: The Duke entertain'd a fellow to looke to his buildings, and this fellow drown'd himſelfe, it was my fate to bring the news to the Court, which when the young
Dutcheſs heard, ſhe grew preſently as mad as a march Hare; now demanding reward for my news, the Duke out of his bounty ſaid, be would baniſh me the Court; now I would faine know what ſum of money the word baniſh'd ſignifies.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It ſignifies, that if thou dar'ſt preſume
To come within the Court gate, thou incur'ſt
The Dukes diſpleaſure, it is preſent death.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You will not buy my reward ſir, will you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then I ſee thou art a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But is the Dutcheſs frantique?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ile aſſure you ſhe's a mad wench.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And how did the Duke take it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh very diſcontentedly: and he hath proclaim'd to him that can cure her of her frenzy to have the next thing he ſhall aske without exception.

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.l: But art thou ſure 'tis true?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I aſſure you my friend as true as I am baniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That cure Ile undertake, and ſo prevaile,
That I preſume my cunning ſhall not faile.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Now ſir I have reſolv'd you of all theſe doubts, can you tell me how I ſhall beſtow my ſelfe now I am baniſh'd?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I can, I am a ſtranger in this City,
And I profeſſe darke arts, Phyſick, and Negromancy,
And for a need can conjure; but direct me
Where I may lodge and freely uſe my Art,
Ile entertaine thee and ſupply thy wants
With all things needfull.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: As bountifull as wiſe; I am for you ſir ſo you will teach me wit; I have ſeen the Duke and his Court, but never to my knowledge ſaw a wiſe-man afore, you are the firſt of the name that ever I look'd on; but if it be nothing but a Lodging you want, truſt to me, I can furniſh you with that at an houres warning.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Direct me to the place.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That I will ſir as well as I can,
Be you the wiſe Maſter, Ile be the wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Attend me then, her choice love I have found,
I made the hurt, and I can cure the wound. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, and Iulio.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Her fits encreaſe then dayly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They ſtill grow,
Sometimes her eyes with ſalt teares over-flow;
She fills the houſe with Muſique, and then wrings
Her Ivory hands, ſhe dolefully laments,
At once expreſſing thouſand diſcontents.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Proclaime to him that can her frenzy cure
The next thing he can aske.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord leave theſe diſcontents to ſome further leaſure, we are now at the ſtrange Knights Lodging to give entertainment to the Spaniſh Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: True, we are his invited gueſts, and it is not fit that our grievances ſhould any way appeare to a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You counſell well, behold this is his Lodging—
sp.l: And here's the Knight himſelfe. Enter Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord to a poore ſtrangers Lodging,
My beautious Lady and my Love's arriv'd,
Whoſe grace I firſt wonne in a Turnament,
Bearing the prize from many Knights of Spaine;
Pleaſe you to grace me at a ſolemne feaſt
Which I prepar'd this day to welcome her,
You ſhall do much honour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Knight I will,
And for thy ſake reſpect her to her worth;
How doſt thou like thy Lodging built ſo neare
This Caſtle where Valentia lies inclos'd?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My Lord, 'tis well for proſpect and for aire,
Wil't pleaſe you enter Lords, where be my ſervants. Ex. (Hoboys A Banquet.

div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Iulio, Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is this the place?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is my Lord; but I muſt crave your pardon,
We want that order, and that entertainment,
That obſervation and decorum now
That longs to your eſtate and ſoveraignty,
Yet our good thoughts above our power are large
And full of zeale.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, th'art at too much charge.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your Highneſſe to poſſeſſe your ſeat,
Homely your Viands, but your welcome's great.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But where's the Lady?
She ſhould be Miſtris of the feaſt to day—

div.stage: Enter Valentia like a Spaniſh Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She is not far, ſee yonder where ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis Valentia.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sure 'tis Valentia in this ſtrange diſguiſe▪
Or can you once againe deceive my eyes?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Daughter on my life, her eye, her brow,
Her every part; ha, are my eyes my own?
Here hang my keyes▪ the doores faſt barr'd and lock'd;
Nor is ſhe ſubtile ſpirit, compos'd aire,
To creep though key-holes, or to crawle through chinkes;
Tuſh, tuſh, one Lady may be like another,
And my ſuſpect is cauſeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Let me entreat you
To take your ſeat, My Ladie's but a ſtranger,
And unacquainted with th' Italian guiſe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Obſerve her well my Lords.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She hath her bluſh.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Her lip, her front.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The right trick of her eye.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But is it ſhe, is't poſſible the Knight
Would be ſo bold, ſhe ſo audacious?
It cannot be; come, now I take my place.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: In this your Highneſſe doth your ſervant grace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: E • ha nos de bener dies benediga toda la Compania ſeias & bien venido.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What ſaies the Lady?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She cals for wine and bids you welcome all.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The very touch and accent of her tongue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signeur yo b ••• an de buen corac • n.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Her meaning.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She drinks to you with a good heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Tell her I pledge gladly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Doubtleſſe 'tis ſhe, can it be otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why ſpend we time in cups and banquets here,
When faire Valentia muſt be needs transform'd
Unto this ſtranger-Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Still the more
That I obſerve her I am more confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe, ſome devill or witch elſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When face, and tongue, and each thing proves her mine,
Why ſhould I doubt to challenge her? Ile ſuddenly
Call on her name, and if ſhe anſwer to't
Dobtleſſe 'tis ſhe, Valentia—no.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What meanes your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nothing, nay nothing; ſee the very Ring
Upon her finger, I can ſit no longer;
My Lords, I muſt entreat your patience,
I have dropt a Jewell as I came along,
And muſt find it or it will go wrong.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A Jewell loſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Let's help his Grace to ſeek it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pray do my Lords.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Some Torches there.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lights for the Lords, 'twas dropt ſure by the way,
Help him to ſeeke it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Look well there in the Ruſhes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Haſte through the private doore, off with that habit;
If this paſſe currant we are paſt all feare,
Your Father's gone in poſt, why do you ſtay?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have the odds, for mine's the nearer way;
Farewell ſweet Proſpero. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Seek till your eyes be blind,
You ſhall loſe her though you the Jewell find;
How Fortune ſmiles upon our cunning ſhifts,
They are buſie all at worke, the Duke himſelfe
Is like a Jaylor gingling of his keyes,
Which ſerves her as a watch-word to uncaſe;
If now our plot prove, there depends on this
All our ſucceeding hopes, and future bliſſe— Ent. Val, above.
Valentia, Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What, at your book already?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes ſir, to pray
After theſe tempeſts for a calmer day.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The Duke's at hand, and ſeeking how to croſſe
Our loves hath all his Lords left at a loſſe— Enter Man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Body of me ſhe's here; foole that I am
Her loyalty to miſtruſt, or his good thoughts,
She being chaſte, he honeſt; how now Lady,
What at your booke ſo cloſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Books are Companions
To them who are compell'd to ſingle lives.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou art ranke 'mongſt Virgins.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Virgins would be wives—Why come you ſir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Only my girle to ſee
How well thou fareſt, thou one day ſhalt be free;
Fare well, in this my jealouſie appeares,
And this one feare begets a thouſand feares. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not without cauſe, good Father, knew you all;
But I muſt down the next way through the wall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By this ſhe's comming, be thou firſt faire love,
Or elſe our ſtratagem is quite o'rthrown,
But if't take place, Valentia is mine own;
How will the Duke look when he finds her here▪
And in his heart condemne his needleſle feare!
He hath not wit to trace us in our drifts,
True love is cunning and hath thouſand ſhifts— Enter Val.
Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prince Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And in your habit too, all ſucceeds happily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Harke, harke, my Father is at hand my Lord,
Ile keepe my place as if I had not mov'd,
Who ever ventur'd fairer where they lov'd— Enter Mantua

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How now my Lord, what is the Jewell found▪

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'T was never loſt, I left it in my Cloſſet,
Where it was ſafe, 'twas but my jealous feare
And blind miſtake, but now thoſe doubts are paſt,
For where I found it I have lock'd it faſt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your Grace to ſit—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have look'd my eyes almoſt blind,
And yet I can no Jewell find.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure if it had been a Diamond, or any ſtone that had had either luſtre or quickneſſe, I ſhould have ſeen it ſparkle.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lords, you may ſpare your paines,
The Jewel's found.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Lords, ſeat your ſelves, and grace this ſtrangers banquet,
And ſpeake what news is in the City rifeſt,
For you frequent i • moſt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They ſay, my Lord, there is a Negromancer,
One of rare art and cunning, that can truly
Tell of things loſt, one that hath Ephemerides
At his fingers ends; no frenzy, feaver, ſickneſs,
But he hath Cordials for, ſo his large bils,
Paſted on every poſt, ſpeak in his praiſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And where reſides he?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here in the City Mantua.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Some Mountebanke fellow.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It ſhould not ſeem ſo,
For he hath much reſort, and every mouth
Proclaimes his skill.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will make triall of him,
To know if my love-ſute ſhall well ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ile try his cunning.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ile be his Client.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: So will I,
And in my deepe affaires his beſt skill try.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ile prove him in the beautious Dutcheſs cure,
In which if he prevaile his paines ſhall be
Paid from the beſt of all his Treaſury;
We ſit too long, ſtranger, we praiſe thy bounty,
And if in any ſute thou wilt uſe our love,
Suppoſe it, crav'd, granted.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I ſhall find time my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I cannot he at reſt
Till I have once more ſearch'd her private Chamber to aſſure and
Of theſe doubts; ſtrange: farewell,
Only my keyes can theſe ſad doubts expell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Haſte, haſte to meet your Father in the Tower.
Shortly will come the long expected houre. Exit.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Table with a Booke and Papers ſet out.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: YOu ſee I have purchas'd you a Lodging at the houſe of mine own fleſh and bloud, otherwiſe call'd my Father; now ſir, if you do not ſhew your ſelfe a Maſter of your Art, or your Crafts-Maſter, you ſhall but diſgrace your ſelfe, and call the reputation of my Fathers houſe in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Tuſh, feare not me, what cannot I performe,
A maske of naked wenches I could bring
To dance ſtrange Antiques here, and none but we
To be ſpectatours.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh brave man, when ſhall we ſee this ſport?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Doſt thou love ſweet meats? I have chang'd e're now,
Againſt a Chriſtning day, a ſhowre of haile
To perfect Comfets that have ſerv'd a feaſt,
And I can do't againe, but tuſh 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh ſweet man, here's one that by his Art is able to undo all the Comfet-makers in Chriſtendome,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What meat doſt thou love beſt?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I love many meates well, and indeed ſcarce any comes
amiſs, if it be come in his right likeneſs, when I have a ſtomack I can eate Capon and Rabit, but above all meats, not to diſſemble, I love a good peece of roaſted beefe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ile tell thee what once I did in Germany.
There was a hill lay juſt againſt the Sun,
I by my art chang'd it to perfect beefe▪
Which the violent heat of the Sun roaſted as
Perfectly as any ſea coale fire, and ſtill as it
Was enough the Country people came with their
Sharpe knives and cut it off in ſlices.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh that my journey had laine over that hill.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now ſir a brooke ran by of cleare water,
And that I turn'd to perfect vinegar
For ſauce to that roſt-beefe, and the ſmall ſand
Was chang'd to perfect pepper; now ſir, it
Was but bringing •• ead along with them and flicing away
A peece of the hill, and ſitting downe by the Rivers ſide,
And there was as good roſt beefe, vinegar, and pepper
As any man in Mantua could deſire to eate.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This cunning man hath a trade would ſet any mans teeth a wat'ring that hath but a ſtomack— Enter Proſpero.
But ſoft, here come ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: If the wiſe man be as cunning as rumour reports him,
Ile know what ſhall betide me in my love-affaires;
This, I this, by my directions ſhould be the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My Coſin the Prince, excellent, Ile put him
Into a pittifull perplexity e're we part.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Now will I try whether this fellow have any cunning or no, thou learned man of Mantua heaven ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thou worthy Gentleman of Verona, I thanke thee,
Nay, I have given 't you, pick out the meaning of that.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He knows me to be of Verona.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I, and an enemy to the Duke of Mantua,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You wrong me ſir, I love the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I, and his Daughter too, pray do you no • ?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: A rare admirable fellow, he knows all, I muſt collogue with him, or hee'l reveale all my ſecrets to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, herein, moſt learned, I muſt needs ſay you erre;
and though I will not ſay your devill is a Lyer, becauſe I am altogether unacquainted with him, yet in this I muſt needs tell you he is in the wrong, for this Gentleman is a true Trojan, a Knight Errant, and one that hath fought at the Tombe of adventures.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Indeed I am a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Indeed you are a diſſembler.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My name's Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Otherwiſe call'd Prince Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The rareſt fellow in Chriſtendome; upon my life he knows my very thoughts, my meditations.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come hither you, you that can gull the Duke,
Make private doores into his Daughters Tower▪
And whil'ſt your Noble Father, good old man,
Thinkes you abroad in travell to ſee faſhions,
You loyter here about a Ladies love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh wonderfull, I never heard the like▪

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now wheres the Ring the Duke ſpi'd on your finger?
When was the merry meeting with your friend
And the two Ladies when they talk'd aſleep,
And by that ſudden ſhift deceiv'd the Duke?
Where's the ſtrange Spaniſh Lady? where's the banquet
To which you did invite him?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He knows all, all by this light,
There's nothing left unknown.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Here's no roguery, here's no knavery, here's no villany, and all confeſt too, Ile even, like a good Subject, make all this acquainted to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet Conjurer, good Mephaſt ophilus,
Ile give thee here a hundred Duckets ſtraight
But keep my counſell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But if the wiſe-man will, the foole will not; nay, and there be ſuch knaveries in hand, you had better never have let them come to my eare, the Duke ſhall know all, all by this hand, nay, that's moſt certaine—truſt to it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Stay ſirrah, or Ile bring you back with a whirlewind.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not I moſt learned, you ſhall pardon me, Ile be no Traytour for no mans pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Prethee come back.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No ſuch matter, have you ſuch fagaries, Ile tell the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You doore-maker.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How moſt wiſe?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The Duke ſhall know of making of that doore
By which the Prince had free way to the Lady,
You were his Overſeer.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No more, ſweet Doctor Fauſtus, no more.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sirrah, you had better been a doore keeper than a doore-maker.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then I had better be a theefe than a knave, ſilence noble Scholler, and I am at thy ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well ſirrah, keep his Counſell and Ile keep yours, and whileſt I ſpeak a few words with this ſtranger, do thou watch there, and looke ſtedfaſtly at the kitchin window, for about dinner time there will flye in Capons, Pigeons, Pigs, Geeſe, Larks, Chickens all ready roaſted, with every one a knife at his girdle to cut himſelfe up, do but thou watch and bring me word when they come flying in and call me; wee'l to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh rare, ready roaſted! I would I were a wiſe man too, as I ſhall never bee whileſt I live; it is nothing but ſpreading a cloath, laying trenchers, ſetting a ſalt, providing of bread, and making platters and ſauce ready, and your roaſt-meat will come as duly every one flying to his own diſh and ſauce as Crows in the evening fly to their own neſts; Ile get him to tile our houſe with Biskets, to pave the Kitchin with Cuſtards, to make our Lo •… e-walls of Ginger-bread, and turne our Cheeſe-trenchers into Wafer-cakes; Ile watch, but if I bring him word till I have fill'd my belly, may my girdle break.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Montecelſo turn'd a wiſe man!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I know that's more than ever thou didſt looke for at my hands.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Beſhrew thee Coz, thou haſt put me into two pittifull plunges, firſt thy death, next for this needleſſe feare.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I thought as ſurely thou hadſt been in heaven
As I know this is earth: introth mad Coz,
And haſt thou gone beyond me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Now I hope: no, that was a Crow that flew over our houſe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Be confident for I have caſt a plot.
How thou ſhalt ſteale away thy Love to Church,
And make her Father with his own free hand
Give her to thee in marriage; more than this,
Put ſtrange diſgraces on thy oppoſites
And ſuch as are thy rivals; wouldſt thou thinke
Me a perfect wiſe man to contrive this well?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: More wiſe than I firſt knew thee.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: For this time part, earely to morrow morning
Convey Valentia through the private doore
Suted as at the Banquet; next invite
The Mantuan Duke to grace your Nuptials
In Saint Lauretta's Chappell; what remaines
Shall all be mine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My deareſt friend adieu,
No cunning head had e're a heart ſo true. Exit.—Knock.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Harke, ſome one knocks.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Moſt prudent.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Leave ſtaring to the kitch. till anon,
And let me in theſe Gallants.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Beſhrew their hearts for me, belike they heard what good cheere was flying towards our houſe, and now like bold gueſts they are come to bid themſelves to dinner; I will let them in, though I could wiſh them choak'd for their paines—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Who takes his turne firſt?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That will I ſo pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I know them all, their buſineſſe, their affaires,
And I ſhall fit them finely; grave old man,
My choiceſt welcome I beſtow on you,
And welcome Lords to all, but firſt you:
I know my Lord of Florence you affect
The amorous Lady faire Valentia.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Oh marvelous!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But you the frantique Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Poſſible.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, come, I know the inmoſt of your thoughts,
Then to be briefe and cut off circumſtance,
Harke you my Lord of Florence, do but this,
And Ile aſſure you faire Valentia's love,
Tomorrow morning muſt the ſtranger Knight
In Saint Lauretta's Chappell wed his Love,
The Spaniſh Lady, given him by the Duke,
Whil'ſt they are buſied watch the new-built Tower,
In which by Art I will contrive a doore,
Which you ſhall find wide open.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Oh rare man!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Through which paſſe freely; now to blind ſuſpicion,
Becauſe you may not be deſcried or known,
Weare ſome diſguiſe, this paper ſhall direct you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou moſt ingenious Artiſt, take this Gold,
The happy earneſt of my future love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Enough my Lord, now waite upon my skill;
And now to you, I know you love the Dutcheſs,
But ſhe is chang'd by ſickneſſe; yet my Lord
If you will marry faire Valentia,
Who for your love diſdaines the Florentine,
Ile ſet you down a courſe to compaſſe it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Either will ſerve my turne, I'm not ſo curious
To thy my fancy to one womans face.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Know, through my ſpirits help, I have digg'd a doore
Quite through the Turrets doore, which wall leads ſtreight
Unto the Ladies Chamber, take this note,
This Paper ſhall direct you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There's Gold for Paper.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My turne is next;
I am a ſtranger to thee, learned Friend,
Nor doſt thou know my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: No Lord Julio.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Iulio I'm call'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And love that Lady
Whom theſe two Princes tenderly affect.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Th'art ſomething neare me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ile come nearer yet,
To the two ſtrangers I could tell your hate,
Th'one drown'd, t'other Guardian of the Tower,
But my Art's no accuſer.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Noble Schollar,
Let this Gold bribe thy art to ſecreſie,
And teach me how I may prevent their plots,
Gaine the Dukes Grace, and faire Valentia's love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This Paper ſhall do all, peruſe it then,
And let it be your Tutor, ſo now leave me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: with all my art Ile prove thy magick skill,
And to the utmoſt what thou plot'ſt fulfill, Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Adieu; you ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Moſt judicious.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Follow them with ſpeed,
Watch them, and when thou ſeeſt them neare the Tower,
Run to the Duke and call his armed Guard
To apprehend theſe Miners that have digg'd
Unlawfull paſſage through his high-built Tower,
See them well beaten, and after come to me,
And I will teach thee this rare Negromancy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Feare not, Maſter Doctor, firſt Ile play my part,
And after come to you to learne your Art. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now ſir to you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And what to me ſir? thinke not with your tricks
To draw me in opinion you are wiſe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Were not your Grace a man I reverence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My Grace, what Grace? you'd gull me would you not?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nor can you gull me moſt excellent Lord,
You are Verona's Duke; nay, never ſtart,
For to your care my tongue's cloſe as your heart;
I know that Mantua loves you not, yet know
Your Son ſerves Mantua as a friendly Foe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon me ſir, I now approve your cunning,
Conceale my being, and expect reward—
But ſee the Duke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What liberall reprover, I perceive
You find ſome matter in this man of note.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Matter indeed my Lord, this is a man
Exceeding many other private men,
That are indeed but ſhaddows, counterfeits,
This man hath naturall gifts joyn'd with his Art.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We like your praiſe, and will our ſelfe applaud
His excellence, if by his grounded skill
He can give caſe to this faire Dutcheſs griefe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What Mortalls can attempt Ile undertake;
This is the Lady, and I know her griefe
Ariſes from a ſullen melancholly;
She has loſt ſome friend, the ſorrow of whoſe death
Hath turn'd her ſanguine ſtreames of bloud to black.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Black, loſt, gone, ſunke, fled, adieu, farewell,
The waves have quite undone poore Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Tuſh, I can cure this madneſſe preſently.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: How learned Friend? reſtore her to her ſenſes,
And the next thing that thou demand'ſt is thine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I know the perfect temper of her griefe,
Which that you may perceive Ile cure with Art;
I will raiſe up the Ghoſt of him ſhe lov'd,
So like in all things you your ſelves ſhall ſweare
It is the man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Shall he appeare to us?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Here to you all, but ſtir not, move no foot,
Take heed you do not queſtion him too far,
But only heare and ſee, and ſtand aloofe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But will he not afright us?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Not a jot;
Looke to the Lady, Ile about my Art,
And ſend the Architector preſently, Exit.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Well, if I ſee him I will chide him ſo,
That he ſhall never drowne himſelfe againe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is't poſſible this can be done by Art?
Or meanes he to delude us?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: So it ſeemes, for I ſhall ne'r more ſee my Love again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sweet Lady be content.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You ſee I am.
The ſound may give whole counſel to the ſick,
Away, your counſell does encreaſe my paine,
And I ſhall ne'r more ſee my Love againe—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He's come already.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Lord how like he is!
Would you not ſweare it were the very man;
An admirable Artiſt I ſee he wafts the Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh thou deare ſoule of my ſweet Love deceas'd,
Ile follow thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Stir not, it is the Devill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Spirit or fiend, his amorous ſhape ſo charmes,
Did he graſpe hell I'd flie into his armes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The Devill hath born her hence, follow and reſcue her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not I my Lord, your Grace ſhall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh what black treſpaſſe hath ſhe done 'gainſt heaven
That ſhe ſhould thus be hurried quick to hell;
Now is ſhe hopeleſſe, paſt recovery;
Ile hang that Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Condemn him not before you ſee the event.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What can the event be but her utter loſſe?
Oh my faire Dutcheſs, if thou periſh thus,
Ile make that baſe Inchanter curſe this day,
For thy loſt bloud his traitcrous head ſhall pay—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How cheeres my Lord, did you behold the Ghoſt?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We ſaw the Devill, but ſpeake, where's the Dutcheſs?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Safe in my Chamber, where before to morrow,
Your Grace ſhall ſee her perfectly recover'd,
Doubt not my Art; but there remaines, my Lord,
For you a further buſineſs, the ſtrange Knight
Expects the Spaniſh Lady from your hand
In Saint Lauretta's Chappell, whither I promiſe
To bring your Lady perfectly recover'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: See this done,
And the next thing that thou demand'ſt is thine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I ſhall make bold, my Lord, to claime your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Claime it and take it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You'l truſt her in my Chamber for this night,
For I muſt phyſick her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do what thou pleaſeſt, it highly ſhall content me;
Come, let's returne to Court, and there attend
Of our precedent feares a fortunate end. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thou haſt no part in that faire fortunate end,
It 'longs to me, and to my noble friend: Madam—

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh my deare Love how could you ſo delude
A Lady that with ſuch intire affection
And zealous love admir'd and honour'd you!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Of that no more; the Duke for this great cure
Hath promis'd me what I ſhall next demand,
I have a boone to aske, I have ſet on foot
Many ſtrange plots which muſt their full effect
Receive this night, the Prince is to eſpouſe
The faire Valentia by the Dukes free gift,
Florence, Ferrara, and Lord Iulio,
His Rivals, are about their ſeverall tasks;
Something there remaines for me, amongſt the reſt,
And you to act out of theſe confuſions,
We muſt deviſe our fortunes to ſecure,
And ſave that love that is ſo chaſte and pure. Exeunt. Hoboys.

div.stage: Enter at one Doore a Biſhop, Mantua, and Verona, fetch Profpero and Valentia, Mantua makes ſome ſtrange pauſes, viewing the Lady exactly, at length (recalling his hand once or twice) troath-plights them, and ſo march over to the Church.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: In this diſguiſe who can know Iulio now.
Or gueſſe the purpoſe that I have in hand?
This Paper tells me I ſhall find a doore
Left open to Valentia's amerous bed: here Ile waite
The happy end of my auſpicious Fate—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So I am fitted ſo un willingly
That I ſcarce know my ſelfe; yet as this Paper
Gives me directions may I find the Doore
Left open to me, I deſire no more—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A Carpenter I ſhould be, would this Apron
And Rule bring me to rule in Mantua
By marriage of the faire Valentia,
I ſhould applaud my fortunes, and commend
The wiſe mans Art; this can imperious love, Ent. Clo. and Guard.
Whoſe power hath oft tranſhap'd the gods above.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You ſhall be tranſhap'd Ile warrant you, wee'l teach you to take upon you other mens trades before you be free of their Companies; if your Rule at your back will not rule you, we will; ſtand cloſe Gentlemen, and though we find them broad awake, let's ſee if we can take them napping.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The doore, according to to the wiſe-mans words,
I find wide open, Ile enter.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why pauſe I being ſo neare?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ile enter inſtantly, but ſoft, I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Company, now muſt I counterfeit to worke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To ſhun diſcovery,
Ile ſee how I can play the Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now to my Maſonry.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would I were ten Leagues off.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Upon them Gentlemen, upon them, theſe be the underminers I told you of, up with your Poleaxes and down with them, ſee they have broken open a doore already, they ſhall be arraigned of Burglary.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hold, hold, and heare us.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Bumbaſte them Gentlemen, currifeige them bravely, heare them after; palt the Maſon with ſtones, hammer the Smith, & over-rule the Carpenter, come, away with em. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My Son is married to the Mantuan Princeſſe,
A Lady of that preſence and opinion,
That it offends me not; but to prevent
Any offence that may be done to him,
Or injury to me, I have at hand
A Royall Army under Coſmos charge,
Our truſty and approved Counſellor,
To offer War or Peace—the Duke's at hand. Exit. Floriſh.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How naked is our Traine, that of our Courtiers,
So few attend this high ſolemnity?
Where's Florence? where's Ferrara? where's Lord Iulio?
That have not ſeen us given away this
Daughter I feare, for ſo my eye perſwades;
Had I not in theſe keyes ſuch confidence,
And in the ſtrength of my large edifice,
I ſhould not doubt to ſweare, but theſe Ile truſt,
When ſervants faile, keyes and ſtone-walls prove juſt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thrice worthy ſir, you have given me ſuch a gift,
Should you impart you Dukedomes large revenew
It could not equal't; now your hand is paſt,
Which both your word and Church-rights have made faſt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Twere beſt that I returne to ſee all ſafe▪
And next enquire how my faire Dutcheſſe fares.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, you have committed her
To his protection that undoubtedly
Will ſee to her recovery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So we hope.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Reſtore her to her ſenſes and true feeling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And apt her thoughts for love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That's all we covet.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I have underſtood
By thoſe that know him, ſo much hee'l make good.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then are we truly happy—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Roome for one good Subject that brings three bad Subjects to anſwer Burglary before your Grace: ſee here my Lord, here are three fellows that have good faces and are aſham'd to ſhew 'em, they ſeeme to be ſound men, yet ſee if they do not ſtrive to looke ſcurvily?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What men are theſe? or how have they offended?
Why do they turne their heads thus and looke downwards?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: As if they had ſtolne a pudding.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Theſe faces I ſhould know, my Lord of Florence,
Ferrara's Marqueſſe, and Lord Iulio;
Is this the coſt you have ſo liberally
Beſtow'd to grace our feaſt? my Bride and I
Are much bound to you

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Theſe the men, perhaps they have ſome maske,
If ſo, let's ſee't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Compell me not to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Give me leave
To bluſh and be aſham'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hell take the Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Lords, what meanes this antique▪ if you have
Some ſport to ſhew us▪ pray my Lords let's have't.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How well this ſute becomes you! troth my Lord,
Might I adviſe you, I would ſtill go thus;
Acquaint me with your Taylor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is this the neweſt faſhion?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would I were in the Indies
Rather than here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But tell me ſirrah, what meanes this ſhew?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Call you theſe Lords! no, they are Loones, they looke more like Prentices than Princes; theſe are they that have beleaguered your new Tower, and digg'd a hole through the wall, that an Oxe or an Aſſe, 'bleſſe us, as big as your ſelfe may creepe through; there's a doore made into your Daughters Tower where ſhe was kept, and the doore being left open ſhe is flowne away: Valantia is gone, ſhe is gone, and theſe are they that had their hands in the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Valentia gone, and by their practice loſt!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: By theirs; when they were boring at the hole we took them at it with their tooles out, we tooke them in the manner before they could put up, and here we have brought them to anſwer before your Grace, that you may freely puniſh their weakneſſe that would offer to go to your walls.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Theſe injuries ſeverely wee'l revenge,
But moſt on thee falſe Iulio, for her loſſe
Thy head ſhall pay.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Pox of the Conjurer I ſay ſtill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speake, where's Valentia, can you tell me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then for her loſſe your forfeit lives ſhall go;
Who can adviſe me beſt where I may find
Her I moſt lov'd, and hath prov'd moſt unkind.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Might I adviſe your Grace, I would have you ſhould do as Archers do, that when they have loſt an Arrow, ſhoot another after it; ſo, my Lord, if you have ever another Lady or Miſtris about the Court, ſhoot her after your Daughter, that you may either find one, or loſe both.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Good Counſell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To him that can reduce her to her Tower,
Or put me in poſſeſſion of her hand,
What grace our Power or Dukedome can command
Shall all be his.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I take you at your word, ſee here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This, this is the Spaniſh Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She that ſpoke
In Spaniſh once is forc'd to change her tongue,
Pardon deare Father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ha! am I then o're-reach'd? is't poſſible
For all my Coſt, Charge, Care, and diligence
A Wenches wit out-go me? could her ſubtiltie
Make way through that which not an Army could?
What ſhould I ſay?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thoſe Creatures that weare ſmocks
Will where they love pierce ſtone-wals, creep through locks;
Why thus you ſee, as well as we, a great man may be gull'd,
Woodcocks are meat, but not to eat untill that they be pull'd. Ex.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That private doore, my Lord, I now perceive
Was made by him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, remember you
The Ring you ſpied upon his finger once,
Then thinke upon the doore.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You made us toſſe the ruſhes
And ſeeke the Jewell, did you? Speake, what art thou
That thus haſt gull'd the Duke?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am a Prince,
And every way thy equall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I would to heaven it were no worſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He is no leſſe my Lord, receive him then to grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Of Whence?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Verona.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Was't not a friendly part
To lodge your only child ſo neare my heart?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord, remember he once ſav'd your life,
And even for that deſerves me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Now as a friend a friendly League I crave,
Take not away what you ſo freely gave.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will pauſe upon't, although it be paſt help,
And ſee what we may puniſh, what forgive;
But now my only comfort is ſtor'd up
In the faire Dutcheſſe, if ſhe gaine her health— Ent. Dutch. and Mont.
And here ſhe comes, I cannot chooſe but feare
So long as I behold you Ghoſt ſo neare.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That Conjurer
Is a rare Artiſt that can raiſe a ſhadow
So like unto the Subſtance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Faire Dutcheſſe, art thou recover'd, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Thanke heaven I am.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis well done to have heaven ſtill in thy thoughts
Being ſo neare a feind, come from that Devill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, I am ſo arm'd with faith,
And love withall, he hath no power to hurt me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Art thou well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, I am well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come from him, but art thou very well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Very well my Lord I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Perfectly well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: So well you cannot wiſh me better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come hither then.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I was of late but ill,
Then give me leave, my Lord, to keep my ſelfe
Well while I am well.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That's with me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Can the Ghoſt ſpeake too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speake, and talke, and walke,
Embrace and kiſle.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I love no kiſſing Ghoſts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Beleeve me, that Magician was a man
Of rare experience, and deſerves great praiſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Did he not ſay before what he ſhould do,
That Ghoſt doth act his part exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I ſay come from him, he's a ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I do not love to do any thing but with a ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He came out of hot hell.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Hee'l make the warmer bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Further than you have been, be not deceiv'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That's far enough already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am the man I ſeem, no Architector,
But Coſin to that noble Gentleman
Prince Proſpero, of the Duke Verona's Court,
That for this Dutcheſſe love have thruſt my ſelfe
Into this imminent danger, as the Prince
Hath done the like for his Valentia;
You promis'd me if I could cure this Lady,
The next thing I demanded, her I crave,
Whom if I truly merit let me have.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I have been gull'd on all ſides, nor will I
Put up theſe injurious wrongs, you both ſhall dye— Ent. Iul.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To arms, to arms my Lord, for I deſcry
A potent Army marching before our walls,
And by their Colours flying they ſhould be of Verona.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Be they from whence they will wee'l parley them;
Admit their Generall to an interview Floriſh.
To know their cauſe of Arms— Enter Verona.
Our Clinick turn'd a Souldier I

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Noble Father I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I the like my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Stand on our party then whil'ſt I debate
Our purpoſe with this Duke; theſe Armes we levied
With no intent of wrong to Mantua,
But to ſecure our Son, and this his friend,
VVe do proteſt it is no worke of ours
That he is married, neither did we wiſh't▪
But ſince by heaven and fate they are united,
We rather wiſh they may their Loves enjoy,
Than what heaven ſeems to applaud we ſhould deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To plead in Armes 〈◊〉 beſt way to prevaile,
VVhere ſtill the weak'ſt muſt yield; ſince our own blond
Hath had an equall ſhare in this our wrong,
Why ſhould we envy ſtrangers, we will ſtrive
From the worlds eye to hide this ominous ſcarre;
Heaven offers peace, why ſhould we threaten war?
Each where they love joyne hands.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Our hearts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A ſweet Concluſion.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And now Madam Ile make you amends for mocking you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Great men are ſometimes gull'd, but that's not common,
You have done more, for you have gull'd a woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your Son, Verona, and his friend hath much
Outſtrip'd us by their wit, but the beſt is
We are not gull'd alone,
You ſee your greatneſſe is no priviledge
From thoſe that have quick braines, but now all friends;
Verona we embrace, and thus attone
All our difſentions; Marriage ſhall conclude
What Armes hath menac'd; our united Dukedomes
Since by this happy fate they are agreed,
Wee'l ſtrive which moſt in bounty ſhall exceed.
